paper.title: 2025年6月英语六级听力真题（第二套）

questions.question_text: What can be learned about the candidates?

options.text: They have to make a choice by the end of the day.
Both candidates are very keen on getting the job.
They hold different views on the procedure.
Both candidates are quite competitive.

questions.question_text: What is said about Rachel and Peter?

options.text: Both Rachel and Peter came across as respectful and professional.
Rachel scored moderately higher grades than Peter at school.
Both Rachel and Peter excelled in their academic pursuit.
Peter appeared slightly stronger than Rachel physically.

questions.question_text: What was impressive about the candidate?

options.text: His use of body language.
His accumulation of experience.
His unusual state of mind.
His knowledge about the company.

questions.question_text: What will the speakers probably do next?

options.text: Compare the candidates side by side again.
Find a way to break the tie next time.
Ask the board to cast the deciding vote.
Let John make the final decision.

questions.question_text: What are the speakers talking about?

options.text: The private label "L'Orange".
The woman's latest collection.
This season's new fashion.
The head designer's role.

questions.question_text: What kind of fashion does the woman prefer?

options.text: Something reflecting the social norms.
Something meeting public expectations.
Something slightly absurd.
Something a bit ambiguous.

questions.question_text: What does the woman try to do in her design?

options.text: Merge styles often at opposite ends of the fashion spectrum.
Learn from the designs of the Asian rural mountain villagers.
Make velvet capes look both majestic and masculine.
Draw intricate patterns onto a traditional power suit.

questions.question_text: What is the man looking forward to?

options.text: Obtaining the woman's signature.
Seeing the woman's new creations.
Incorporating indigenous aspects into his work.
Sharing more ideas with the woman next time.

questions.question_text: What is said about the animals in the study?

options.text: They could readily recognize their owner simply by looking.
They could understand the implications of human commands.
They could be domesticated to act as our companions.
They could follow pointing gestures without training.

questions.question_text: What should be the focus in dealing with these animals?

options.text: Cultivating them to be intelligent creatures.
Training them to behave like domesticated dogs.
Understanding how humans impact their behavior.
Taking measures to reduce their numbers.

questions.question_text: What is suggested regarding these animals?

options.text: Tame them through repeated training.
Treat them with sensitivity and respect.
Make them responsive to our commands.
Watch their behavior and try to improve it.

questions.question_text: What do we learn about the refrigerator?

options.text: The temperature inside it varies from place to place.
Proper placement facilitates access to food products.
Its different shelves are designed for different purposes.
The space in an average fridge changes from top to bottom.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the fridge's design?

options.text: To slow the rising of temperature in it.
To provide a big box of evenly cold air.
To prevent germs from growing quickly.
To keep the food cold as long as possible.

questions.question_text: Where is the warmest place in the fridge?

options.text: On the top shelf.
In the middle section.
On the inside of its doors.
At the back of its bottom shelf.

questions.question_text: What will happen if raw meat is placed on the top shelf?

options.text: They will be extra-chilly.
They will be hard to defrost.
They will be contaminated.
They will be ruined.

questions.question_text: What is the most serious health problem for the elderly?

options.text: Chronic depression.
Growing feebleness.
Hip fracture.
Fatal infections.

questions.question_text: What does the speaker say about the research?

options.text: It feels real and relevant.
It contributes to psychology.
It outcompetes lots of academics' research.
It wins recognition outside of Birmingham.

questions.question_text: How does the researcher conduct her study?

options.text: By bringing together experts old and young.
By counting on advanced modem technology.
By making full use of her expertise.
By combining multiple perspectives.

questions.question_text: What is the problem with cooking schools?

options.text: They don't teach basic organization.
They don't focus on teaching techniques.
They attach little importance to recipes.
They hire very few distinguished chefs.

questions.question_text: What does the speaker say about discipline for chefs?

options.text: It's unique to celebrity chefs.
It's a way of transformation.
It's too demanding for them.
It's a way of life to them.

questions.question_text: What should chefs learn from philosophers?

options.text: Respect others so as to be respected.
Use time and resources in a wise way.
Cultivate a habit of self-discipline.
Learn from philosophers earnestly.

questions.question_text: What does the speaker mainly discuss?

options.text: The motive for hard work.
The reason for stagnation.
The basis for self-improvement.
The justification for self-confidence.

questions.question_text: What do people tend to do when they achieve a goal?

options.text: Feel confidence, happiness and satisfaction.
Believe they have achieved their life goals.
Use a key tool for setting ambitious goals.
Stop imagining further progress in life.

questions.question_text: Why is it hard to achieve happiness through goal setting?

options.text: We feel we are always falling behind others.
We have to adapt to the ever-changing goal.
There are various misconceptions about goal setting.
There are always problems with the goal originally set.

questions.question_text: What should we do to achieve happiness according to the speaker?

options.text: A noticeable change in the number of goals to achieve.
Measuring always against the gap rather than the gain.
Measuring where we've come from instead of measuring against the goal.
A proper conception of what we fail to notice in trying to achieve our goals.
